title: 114_hr902
content: The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes certain improvements in the earned income tax credit permanent, strengthens the credit for individuals with no qualifying children, allows taxpayers to claim the credit without qualifying children under certain conditions, and eliminates the disqualified investment income test. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes certain improvements in the earned income tax credit permanent, including an increase in the credit percentage for individuals with three or more qualifying children. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage are specified in a table based on the number of qualifying children. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes permanent the reduction of the marriage penalty by increasing the phaseout amount for joint returns by $5,000. This amount will be adjusted for inflation after 2014. The taxable year begins by substituting `calendar year 2009' for `calendar year 1992'. Rounding rules apply after any increase. A conforming amendment strikes paragraph (3) of Section 32(b) of the Code. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 3. Strengthening the Earned Income Tax Credit for individuals with no qualifying children. The text discusses a special rule for working individuals over the age of 21 but under 25 without qualifying children regarding the Earned Income Tax Credit. This rule exempts them from certain eligibility criteria if they are not full-time students during the taxable year. The text introduces a special rule for individuals aged 21-25 without qualifying children regarding the Earned Income Tax Credit. This rule exempts them from certain eligibility criteria if they are not full-time students during the taxable year. Additionally, procedures will be developed to verify an individual's claim for the credit against information returns related to higher education expenses. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being increased, with adjustments to credit percentages, phaseout percentages, earned income amounts, and phaseout amounts. Inflation adjustments are also being made to certain sections of the tax code. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being increased with adjustments to credit percentages, phaseout percentages, earned income amounts, and phaseout amounts. Inflation adjustments are also being made to certain sections of the tax code. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Taxpayers can receive a credit for individuals with no qualifying children if the children do not have valid Social Security numbers. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals without qualifying children to be eligible for a tax credit. This applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for separated spouses regarding tax filing status. An individual can be considered unmarried for tax purposes if they file separately, live with a qualifying child for more than half the year, and meet certain residency conditions. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Taxpayer can claim credit without qualifying child if another family member claims the child. Taxpayer eligible for credit without qualifying child if another family member claims the child. The amendment applies to eligible individuals without a qualifying child, except when the child is claimed by a parent. The effective date is for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 eliminates the disqualified investment income test in Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Conforming amendments are made to subsections (j)(1)(B)(i) and (j)(2) of the Code. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
